text: hey guys I'm Lindsay and today on sweet
talk I'm making an oldie but goodie this
is a classic coconut custard pie so it's
basically just a flaky pie crust and a
coconut custard filling so to make my
filling I'm doing a one-pot custard
super-easy this is a backup of
granulated sugar 1/3 of a cup of corn
starch this will help thicken the
custard to the right consistency and 1/4
teaspoon of kosher salt and as always a
little salt with our sweet and then I'm
adding 1 cup of whole milk and one can
or 14 ounces of unsweetened coconut milk
and this gives us our coconut flavor for
the coconut custard and for large egg
yolks separate these into a bowl if you
want you can hang on to the egg whites
to make a meringue kind of topping or
use them in another baking project but
today I'm just using the yolks my whisk
these in and right now this is off heat
so you want to make sure that you're
doing all of this off heat all the
measuring and then now that this is
combined I will turn this on over medium
high whisking constantly and you're
waiting for it to start bubbling you
don't have to beat it like crazy but
you're just making sure that the milk
doesn't scald on the bottom of the pan
what I love about this custard recipe is
that there's no tempering of eggs you do
this all in one pot on the stovetop it
could not get easier so this takes a
couple of minutes and you have to be
patient here because if you just crank
up the heat you're gonna curdle your
eggs and you're gonna have a very lumpy
custard and that is really
not appealing to anybody feel with my
whisk it's starting to thicken up a
little bit
so both the cornstarch and the egg yolks

sometimes you'll find a custard that's

smooth at the top just like that now

it's been about four hours and now if I
